course_title: Topics in Chinese Studies: Virtue and its Discontents
class_notes:
Atlas description:
In this course we will explore the moral universe in traditional (pre-twentieth century) Chinese literature. We will focus on the ways that Confucian virtues are represented in literary, philosophical, and religious texts, including essays, records of conversation, short stories, novels, and plays. We will consider how moral questions and the varied answers offered by Chinese traditions might be relevant to our present lives. The materials we will discuss are organized around major keywords such as ritual, sincerity, filiality, chastity, brotherhood, and transcendence, in the spirit of Raymond Williams' exploration of keywords as sites that engage "both continuity and discontinuity, and also deep conflicts of value and belief." 
There are no textbooks required for this course. All readings will be available through Course Reserves and/or Canvas. Readings may include selections from Analects, The Orphan of Zhao, The Three Kingdoms, The Investiture of the Gods, Plum in the Golden Vase, and others.
 
The course fulfills the GER requirements for continuing writing.
